title: Former Norfolk State star Diamond Johnson headed to WNBA Minnesota Lynx camp – Daily Press
body_text:
WNBA
Former Norfolk State standout Diamond Johnson signed a training-camp contract with the WNBA’s Minnesota Lynx.
The Mid-Eastern Athletic Conference Player of the Year, who wasn’t chosen in the WNBA draft, will to report to camp Sunday, three weeks before Minnesota’s first regular-season game.
COLLEGE BASEBALL
Va. State sweeps Apprentice in doubleheader
Virginia State (11-23, 7-11 New South Athletic Conference) swept Apprentice School (22-14, 5-4) in a pair of 4-3 decisions at War Memorial Stadium in Hampton.
In Game 1, VSU’s TJ McGowan, from Chesapeake, was 3 for 4 with a run and an RBI and Hector Rivera, a freshman from Granby High, slugged a home run. The Trojans’ Preston Branzelle (4-6) pitched a four-hit complete game, surviving six walks and Apprentice’s two-run seventh. Builders starter Isaac McCallister (5-4) took the loss.
In Game 2, Jaden Guthrie’s two-run homer in the third and a pair of runs in the fourth off starter Zander Mizelle (4-6) put VSU ahead 4-0. Hunter Johnson’s sacrifice fly and a two-run throwing error in the bottom of the fourth narrowed the gap to 4-3, but VSU’s Gavin Stevens shut out the Builders the rest of the way for a complete-game triumph.
Landon Turner and Gavin Garland each had two hits for Apprentice in Game 2.
Norfolk State road series adjusted because of forecast
Due to inclement weather forecasted in the Hartford area, the Central Connecticut State baseball team has shifted the schedule of its weekend homestand against Norfolk State.
The Spartans and Blue Devils will now open the series with a doubleheader at 1:15 p.m. Friday afternoon, then play the final game of the series at noon Sunday.
COLLEGE MEN’S BASKETBALL
Tribe adds German transfer from Saint Louis
William & Mary coach Brian Earl announced the addition of 6-9 forward Kilian Brockhoff of Cuxhaven, Germany, to the Tribe. He played as a reserve for UC Santa Barbara as a freshman and for Saint Louis as a sophomore. He averaged 2.6 points per game as a freshman and 1.3 as a sophomore.
Brockhoff became the third Division I transfer and fifth member of the Tribe’s class this offseason. He joins a W&M’s incoming group that includes forward Cade Haskins (Dartmouth), forward Jo’el Emanuel (Fairleigh Dickinson), guard Reese Miller (Blinn Community College) and guard Ethan Connery (Casper College).
COLLEGE SOFTBALL
No. 7 Va. Wesleyan sweeps No. 18 Randolph-Macon
No. 7 Virginia Wesleyan (34-3-1, 19-1) swept No. 18 Randolph-Macon 5-0, 7-4 Thursday in Ashland, ensuring the Marlins of the top seed in the Old Dominion Athletic Conference Tournament.
In Game 1, Hannah Hearl (7-2) pitched a seven-inning two-hitter to deal New Kent High alumna Gracie Ellis (18-1) her first defeat of the season. Hearl struck out five and walked two, and the Marlins capitalized on four errors by R-MC (30-8, 15-5) for three unearned runs. Morgan Tucker drove in two runs, and Laci Campbell was 2 for 4 with two runs and an RBI.
In Game 2, Lauren Bible (19-1) gained the victory, giving up two hits, three walks and four runs (two earned) in six innings. Hearl pitched the seventh for the save.
Campbell was 3 for 4 with two runs and an RBI, Olivia Knight was 2 for 4 with a run, Brianna Jones was 3 for 4 and Tucker was 1 for 4 with two runs and an RBI. The Yellow Jackets’ Blayne Talley drove in two runs.
Tucker is the reigning ODAC Player of the Week. She hit .473 with seven RBIs in six games to earn that award.
COLLEGE FOOTBALL
Ex-Hokies QB to play for UCF
Former Virginia Tech quarterback Davi Belfort has committed to play for Central Florida, where Scott Frost — who guided the Knights to a 13-0 season in 2017 that culminated in a Peach Bowl victory over Auburn — has returned as the head coach.
The 5-foot-11, 195-pound Belfort, who was born in Brazil and whose father is mixed martial arts star Vitor Belfort, is expected to have four years of eligibility remaining. He starred for Gulliver Prep in Miami but did not play in a game in his one year with the Hokies.
COLLEGE WOMEN’S GOLF
UVA picked as host of NCAA regional
Virginia will host a regional in the NCAA championships. The event will be held May 5-7 at Birdwood Golf Course in Charlottesville.
The Cavaliers are the No. 2 seed. No. 11 seed Richmond and No. 12 Radford are also in the 12-team regional. Howard sophomore Paris Fieldings, a Chesapeake native who won the Northeast Conference medal at Kingsmill Resort, is one of five individuals who will be competing at Birdwood. She is averaging 74.8 strokes per round this season.
Virginia Tech is the No. 7 seed in Arizona State’s regional.
COLLEGE MEN’S TENNIS
NSU advances to MEAC semis
Third-seeded Norfolk State breezed past second-seeded Coppin State 4-0 to advance to the Mid-Eastern Athletic Conference semifinals in Cary, North Carolina. The Spartans (13-11) will face second-seeded N.C. Central (15-5) at noon Friday.
All-MEAC first-team selection Jakub Solarski joined second-team pick Deniz Okyay in winning 6-0 at No. 2 doubles, helping NSU grab a 1-0 lead. Frederick McRae, a second-team selection, joined Igor Kubalka in winning 6-2 at No. 3.
In singles, No. 1 Vladisav Gorbatenko, No. 3 Okyay and No. 6 Michel Elia won in straight sets, losing just a combined eight games in six sets.
COLLEGE WOMEN’S TENNIS
Spartans roll into conference semis
Fourth-seeded Norfolk State handled fifth-seeded Delaware State 4-0 in Cary, North Carolina, to reach the MEAC semifinals for the first time since 2021.
The Spartans (12-11) will play at 9 a.m. Friday against South Carolina State (13-4), which won its third consecutive regular-season title.
NSU’s Yuliya Yurkova, named to the All-MEAC first team Wednesday, joined Caroline Nicholls for a 6-4 victory on doubles line 3. The Spartans’ Sofiya Tsitavets, who was on the second team, captured a 6-1, 7-5 singles victory on line 1 to follow wins by Nicholls (6-3, 6-2) at 3 and Sabina Iurea (6-0, 6-1) at 5.
PRO TENNIS
Ex-ODU star again advances in Madrid
Former Old Dominion star Yuliia Starodubtseva defeated Italy’s Elizabeth Cocciaretto 7-6 (7-5), 6-4 to continue an impressive run to the round of 32 on clay at the Madrid Open.
Starodubtseva, 25, a Ukrainian ranked 99th in the world, advanced through the qualifying bracket with three-set victories over French players Chloe Paquet (2-6, 6-3, 6-0) and Elsa Jacquemot (7-6 [7-5], 2-6, 7-5).
In the main draw, Starodubtseva beat Czechia’s Linda Fruhvirtova 6-2, 6-2 before knocking off Cocciaretto. The two-time Conference USA Player of the Year’s next foe is the world No. 20, 18th-seeded Liudmila Samsonova.
